content.question: Which of the following conclusions can be made about HBCUsâ€™ contributions to racial equity through the twentieth century?

choices.label: By the end of the twentieth century, the Black Campus movement had encouraged stronger enrollment in HBCUs.
In the early part of the twentieth century, most African American women graduating from HBCUs served in political leadership roles.
By the end of the twentieth century, enrollment in HBCUs continued to offer African Americans opportunities to overcome gaps in racial equity.
Throughout the twentieth century, arts programs at HBCUs promoted global recognition for all students through international tours.

content.answer: By the end of the twentieth century, enrollment in HBCUs continued to offer African Americans opportunities to overcome gaps in racial equity.

topic.text: 3.10: HBCUs, Black Greek Letter Organizations, and Black Education

skill.text: 2.D: Describe and draw conclusions from patterns, trends, and limitations in data, making connections to relevant course content.
